*   **Course Description:**

Intermediate Writing (II) aims to develop students’ writing skills and critical thinking through systematic writing practice. It will provide students with opportunities to write in different modes of discourse. Course time will be devoted largely to discussions of the structural components of academic essays, writing samples, common writing errors, and rhetoric strategies. In addition to lectures, this course will engage students in various writing activities, such as group discussion, peer review and editing.

*   **Course Objectives:**

At the end of this course, students will be able to

1.  identify the structural components of expository writing;
2.  employ different rhetoric strategies for various purposes in writing;
3.  articulate how audience expectation and writing purposes shape writing products;
4.  diagnose and edit their own essays.

*   **Delivery of instruction:**

1.  Lecture
2.  Group discussion & cooperation
3.  Peer review & editing
4.  Student presentation

*   **Grading Policy & Course Requirements:**

**1.     Grading Policy:**

    (1) Attendance, participation & engagement: 15%

    (2) Essays (including original drafts and revisions): 45%

    (3) Three writing podcasts: 15%

    (4) Assignments (e.g., essay outlines, peer review/feedback, others): 15%

    (5) Final podcaster project: 10%

**2\.  Writing Podcasts (15%)**

Writing podcasts are for students to introduce their own essays and reflect upon their writing process. Every student has to hand in three writing podcasts in this semester. More information about the requirements and evaluative criteria for writing podcasts will be announced in class.

**3.  Final Podcaster Project (10%)**

For this project, every student needs to play the role of a podcaster to introduce the three essays he/she completes in this semester. More information about the requirements and evaluative criteria for this podcaster project will be announced in class.

**4\. Classroom Policies:**

1.  Class attendance is a fundamental requirement that will be strictly enforced in this course. Students are required to come to class every week. Absence from **each class period** will result in a 2-point deduction from their attendance/participation/engagement score (except for a valid excuse approved by the instructor). Arriving late to class or leaving early will also count as an absence. Students’ participation and engagement will also be scored based on their levels of contribution to classroom discussions and degrees of effort in learning English writing.
2.  Students are encouraged to participate in group discussions (e.g., group work, peer review, etc.) in English.
3.  Please note that all students are required to submit any of their essays, assignments and podcasts before it is due. Late essays/assignments/podcasts will be marked down by **30%**. Once they are two or more days late, they will NOT be accepted. 
4.  Dishonesty: Academic dishonesty is a misconduct that occurs in academic exercises. It involves plagiarism, cheating, fabrication, etc. Students will be penalized for academic dishonesty on any tests, assignments and exercises.

**4\. Textbook:**

1.  There is no set textbook for this course. Reading materials will be provided.
2.  Recommended materials:

Wyrick, J. (2014). _Steps to writing well_ (12th ed.). MA: Wadsworth.

Carlock, J., Eberhardt, M., Horst, J., & Menasche, L. (2010). _The ESL writer’s handbook_. Michigan: The University of Michigan Press.

Skwire, S. E., & Skwire, D. (2011). _Writing with a thesis: A rhetoric and reader_ (11thed.). MA: Wadsworth.

Free online lecture videos on Coursera: [https://www.coursera.org/](https://www.coursera.org/)
